title: 109_s3514
content: The Act may be cited as the "Social Security Number Online Protection Act of 2006". Congress finds that the inappropriate display of social security numbers has led to various illegal activities, impacting interstate commerce and public safety. The government mandates social security numbers for tax purposes, benefits eligibility, and employment. The misuse of social security numbers for crime and fraud necessitates government intervention to protect individuals' privacy and prevent abuse. In the United States, state and local laws require public documents like business filings and birth certificates to be accessible to the public, potentially including social security numbers. More official records are being stored online, increasing access but also the risk of exposing sensitive information. Increased access to public records online improves accessibility but also raises the risk of widespread display and misuse of social security numbers. SEC. 3 prohibits state and local governments from displaying the last 4 digits of social security account numbers on the internet. Prohibition on displaying last 4 digits of social security account numbers online by State and local governments. Sec. 2732 outlines penalties for states or political subdivisions that do not comply with the prohibition on displaying social security account numbers online. A civil penalty of up to $5,000 per day may be imposed for substantial noncompliance. The Attorney General is authorized to enforce this provision through civil actions. The section outlines penalties for states or political subdivisions that do not comply with the prohibition on displaying social security account numbers online. A civil penalty of up to $5,000 per day may be imposed for substantial noncompliance, and the Attorney General is authorized to enforce this provision through civil actions. Additionally, individuals have the right to seek appropriate relief in United States District Court for the display of the last 4 digits of any social security account number on the Internet in violation of section 2731. The term 'display to the general public on the Internet' is defined as placing any part of a social security account number online. The section outlines penalties for displaying social security account numbers online. A civil penalty of up to $5,000 per day may be imposed for noncompliance. Individuals can seek relief in court for displaying the last 4 digits of a social security number online. Displaying any part of a social security number online is prohibited. The section outlines penalties for displaying social security account numbers online, with a civil penalty of up to $5,000 per day for noncompliance. Any transmittal of an individual's social security account number via the Internet without proper encryption or security measures will be treated as a public display online. The term 'person' refers to an individual, organization, or entity, excluding State agencies. The term 'social security account number' refers to the number assigned by the Commissioner of Social Security, including any derivatives. A new item is added to the table of parts in title 18, United States Code. The amendment prohibits state and local governments from displaying social security account numbers on the internet. Grants are provided to help them comply with the prohibition on displaying the last 4 digits of social security account numbers. Effective date applies to violations occurring after the enactment of the Act. The Attorney General awards grants to States and political subdivisions to remove or redact the last 4 digits of social security numbers from public internet records. The Attorney General awards grants to States and political subdivisions for redacting social security numbers from public records. States must submit an application for the grant, and $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2007 and 2008. The term "State" includes 50 States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Guam, and the Northern Marianas.
